item.title: Croc: Legend of the Gobbos Remaster Release Date Revealed
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/croc-legend-of-gobbos-remaster-release-date

Argonaut Games has announced the release date for the upcoming Croc: Legend of the Gobbos remaster, and it won't be long before you get to revisit this cult platforming classic.

Per a post on social media platform X, Croc: Legend of the Gobbos arrives on PC and consoles on April 2nd. You can wishlist the game on PC now via GOG, but wishlisting isn't yet available for the console platforms; it's coming "soon", according to Argonaut.

If you're wondering what's happened to the Steam version of the game, Argonaut revealed back in October that the game wouldn't be coming to Valve's platform, citing a desire for the game to remain DRM-free on PC (although not on consoles, of course).

If you're not familiar with Croc: Legend of the Gobbos, it's a 3D platformer released for PC, PlayStation, and Sega Saturn (the latter being the platform on which I first played it) back in 1997.

The game was part of a rush of mascot platformers released around that period, going up against the likes of Nintendo's Super Mario 64, Naughty Dog's Crash Bandicoot, and Insomniac Games' Spyro the Dragon, all of which were released within a couple of years of one another.

Croc: Legend of the Gobbos wasn't quite as well-received as the aforementioned titles during its time, but it garnered a cult following, and in August last year, its original publisher Argonaut announced its revival, as well as the game's remaster.

The Croc: Legend of the Gobbos remaster will, of course, sport fresh HD graphics, as well as new controls and an updated camera to make the game's occasionally janky platforming a little less frustrating. You can also expect a Croc treasure trove with lots of materials pertaining to the game's creation.

Croc: Legend of the Gobbos launches on PC via GOG, as well as on PlayStation, Xbox, and Nintendo Switch, on April 2nd.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Retro N64 "Reimagining" Analogue 3D Delayed Once Again
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/analogue-3d-n64-delayed-july

Retro gaming specialist company Analogue has announced that its upcoming Analogue 3D, a "reimagining" of the original Nintendo 64 console, has once again been delayed.

Back in October, the console was delayed until the first quarter of this year, but in an updated FAQ for the machine, Analogue says it's now intended to ship "by July 2025" following a delay. The company doesn't give the reason for said delay.

Analogue does, however, say it's "working hard to get your 3D order in hands ASAP" and that it "appreciate[s] your patience". The company also reiterates that its refund policy is still "no questions asked", so while you don't need to do anything if you're happy with your pre-order, you can cancel it and get your money back if you wish.

In closing, Analogue says that it will email customers a week in advance of the eventual shipping date (which has not yet been announced) to ensure that it has the correct address.

If you're not aware of the Analogue 3D, it's a retro console that's intended to serve as a sort of supercharged N64; it can play any cartridge officially released for Nintendo's console, but it's got a bunch of upscaling tricks up its sleeve.

The Analogue 3D will be fully region-free, and it'll support Bluetooth and Wi-Fi, as well as sporting its own operating system. The console is engineered in FGPA, too, so Analogue says it won't have any of the kind of glitches you might expect from software-level emulation.

Of course, since this is basically a reimagined N64, it'll also feature the same four controller ports included with the original console, and you can even use your original N64 controllers with it, although you may prefer to use the (not included with purchase) 8BitDo 64 controller.

The Analogue 3D is now set to ship in July 2025. You can head over to the store page if you'd like to be notified when it arrives.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Lego Pokemon Sets Officially Announced for 2026
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/lego-pokemon-announced-2026

Lego and The Pokemon Company have announced that a Lego Pokemon collaboration is coming in 2026, although details about the collaboration are fairly scant right now.

The collaboration was announced on the official Lego website today, accompanied by a single teaser image that shows both the Lego and Pokemon logos, as well as what appears to be a Pikachu's tail rendered in Lego form.

As such, we can probably expect to see Pikachu making an appearance in the Lego sets, but considering that the little electric mouse is easily the most popular Pokemon in the world, that shouldn't come as too much of a surprise.

Lego describes the collaboration as "a brand-new collaboration that brings your love for bricks and your love for Pokemon together", asking "Pokemon Trainers" to come together next year to "build and catch some of their favorite Pokemon".

The company goes on to describe its Pokemon crossover as "a real Lego Pokemon adventure", so it sounds like it'll be more than just some sets you can build with bricks; we can, perhaps, expect some interactive elements along the lines of the Lego Mario sets.

If you want to keep up to date with the Lego Pokemon collaboration, you can do so by signing up to the Lego Insiders newsletter program, which will keep you informed about everything to do with the crossover going forward.

Of course, this won't be the first collaboration between Nintendo and Lego; the two have crossed over on the aforementioned Mario Lego sets, as well as sets for Mario Kart and Animal Crossing.

Elsewhere in Pokemon news, the most recent Pokemon Presents showcase showed off the first gameplay footage for Pokemon Legends: Z-A, which is coming in fall this year.

The presentation also revealed a new battling game by the name of Pokemon Champions, as well as several updates to existing Pokemon titles. It's all go for the world's biggest media franchise.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
